Sparse Linear Algebra Reference#

Warp includes a sparse linear algebra module warp.sparse that implements a few common operations for manipulating sparse matrices.

Note

The sparse module is under construction and should be expected to change rapidly, please treat this section as work in progress.

Warning

This module provide naive implementations of useful routines for convenience. For performance, if possible prefer optimized implementations such as provided by cuSPARSE.

Blocked Sparse Row (BSR) matrices#

At the moment, warp.sparse only supports BSR matrix, including the special case of 1x1 blocks, Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) matrices.

class warp.sparse.BsrMatrix#

Untyped base class for BSR and CSR matrices.

Should not be constructed directly but through functions such as bsr_zeros().

nrow#

Number of rows of blocks

Type

int

ncol#

Number of columns of blocks

Type

int

nnz#

Number of non-zero blocks: equal to offsets[-1], cached on host for convenience

Type

int

offsets#

Array of size at least 1 + nrows containing start and end offsets og blocks in each row

Type

wp.array(dtype=int)

columns#

Array of size at least equal to nnz containing block column indices

Type

wp.array(dtype=int)

values#

Array of size at least equal to nnz containing block values

Type

wp.array(dtype=dtype)

property scalar_type: type#

Scalar type for each of the blocks’ coefficients. FOr CSR matrices, this is equal to the block type

property block_shape: Tuple[int, int]#

Shape of the individual blocks

property block_size: Tuple[int, int]#

Size of the individual blocks, i.e. number of rows per block times number of columsn per block

property shape: Tuple[int, int]#

Shape of the matrix, i.e. number of rows/columns of blocks times number of rows/columsn per block

warp.sparse.bsr_zeros(rows_of_blocks, cols_of_blocks, block_type, device=None)#

Constructs an empty BSR or CS matrix with the given shape

Parameters

  • rows_of_blocks (int) –

  • cols_of_blocks (int) –

  • block_type (type) –

  • device (Optional[Union[Device, str]]) –

Return type

BsrMatrix

warp.sparse.bsr_set_from_triplets(dest, rows, columns, values)#

Fills a BSR matrix dest with values defined by COO triplets rows, columns, values.

Values must be either one-dimensional with data type identical to the dest matrix block times, or a 3d array with data type equal to the dest matrix scalar type.

Previous blocks of dest are discarded.

Parameters

  • dest (BsrMatrix) –

  • rows (<warp.types.array object at 0x000001653C4B59C8>) –

  • columns (<warp.types.array object at 0x000001653C4B5A08>) –

  • values (<warp.types.array object at 0x000001653C4B5A48>) –

warp.sparse.bsr_assign(dest, src)#

Copies the content of the src matrix to dest, possibly casting the block values.

Parameters

  • dest (BsrMatrix) –

  • src (BsrMatrix) –

warp.sparse.bsr_copy(A, scalar_type=None)#

Returns a copy of matrix A, possibly asting values to a new scalar type

Parameters

A (BsrMatrix) –

warp.sparse.bsr_set_transpose(dest, src)#

Assigns the transposed matrix src to matrix dest

Parameters

  • dest (BsrMatrix) –

  • src (BsrMatrix) –

warp.sparse.bsr_transposed(A)#

Returns a copy of the transposed matrix A

Parameters

A (BsrMatrix) –

warp.sparse.bsr_get_diag(A, out=None)#

Returns the block diagonal of a square sparse matrix

Parameters

  • A (BsrMatrix) –

  • out (Optional[array]) –

warp.sparse.bsr_set_diag(A, diag)#

Sets A as a block-diagonal square matrix

Parameters

  • A (BsrMatrix) –

  • diag (array) –

warp.sparse.bsr_diag(diag)#

Creates a square block-diagonal BSR matrix from the values array diag

Parameters

diag (array) –

warp.sparse.bsr_axpy(x, y, alpha=1.0, beta=1.0)#

Performs the operation y := alpha * X + beta * y on BSR matrices x and y

Parameters

  • x (BsrMatrix) –

  • y (BsrMatrix) –

  • alpha (float) –

  • beta (float) –

warp.sparse.bsr_mm(x, y, z=None, alpha=1.0, beta=0.0)#

Performs the operation z := alpha * X * Y + beta * z on BSR matrices x, y and z

Parameters

  • x (BsrMatrix) –

  • y (BsrMatrix) –

  • z (Optional[BsrMatrix]) –

  • alpha (float) –

  • beta (float) –

warp.sparse.bsr_mv(A, x, y, alpha=1.0, beta=0.0)#

Naive implementation of sparse matrix-vector product, y := alpha * A * x + beta * y.

Parameters

  • A (BsrMatrix) –

  • x (array) –

  • y (array) –

  • alpha (float) –

  • beta (float) –
